title: Joshua Chapter 22 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Joshua chapter 22 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Joshua Chapter 22 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Joshua Chapter 22.

questions.question: Who did Joshua call at the beginning of Joshua Chapter 22?
options: The Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh
The Levites and the priests
The entire tribe of Judah
The elders of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:1 states that Joshua called the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh.

questions.question: What did Joshua commend the tribes for in Joshua 22:2?
options: Keeping all that Moses commanded and obeying Joshua's voice
Building an altar by the Jordan
Fighting the enemies of Israel
Offering sacrifices in the tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: Keeping all that Moses commanded and obeying Joshua's voice
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:2 says they kept all that Moses commanded and obeyed Joshua's voice in all he commanded.

questions.question: According to Joshua 22:4, what had the LORD God given to the brethren?
options: Rest
Victory in battle
Wealth
A new tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: Rest
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:4 states the LORD God had given rest unto their brethren as He promised.

questions.question: What instructions did Joshua give them in Joshua 22:5?
options: To love the LORD God, walk in His ways, keep His commandments, cleave unto Him, and serve Him with all heart and soul
To build an altar beside the altar of the LORD
To gather much cattle and treasure
To fight the enemies of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: To love the LORD God, walk in His ways, keep His commandments, cleave unto Him, and serve Him with all heart and soul
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:5 instructs them to love the LORD, walk in His ways, keep His commandments, cleave unto Him, and serve Him wholeheartedly.

questions.question: What did Joshua bless the tribes with when sending them back to their tents, according to Joshua 22:8?
options: Much riches, cattle, silver, gold, brass, iron, and raiment
Peace and safety
Victory in battle
A new altar
questions.correctAnswer: Much riches, cattle, silver, gold, brass, iron, and raiment
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:8 says Joshua told them to return with much riches, cattle, silver, gold, brass, iron, and raiment.

questions.question: Where did the children of Reuben, Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh build a great altar according to Joshua 22:10?
options: By Jordan, at the borders of Canaan
In Shiloh
In the land of Gilead
In the tabernacle of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: By Jordan, at the borders of Canaan
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:10 states they built an altar by Jordan, a great altar to see to, at the borders of Canaan.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the children of Israel upon hearing about the altar in Joshua 22:12?
options: They gathered to go up to war against them
They rejoiced and blessed God
They ignored it
They sent gifts to the builders
questions.correctAnswer: They gathered to go up to war against them
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:12 says the whole congregation gathered at Shiloh to go up to war against those who built the altar.

questions.question: Who was sent with princes to speak to the children of Reuben, Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh in Joshua 22:13-14?
options: Phinehas the son of Eleazar the priest with ten princes
Joshua alone
Moses
Elders of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Phinehas the son of Eleazar the priest with ten princes
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:13-14 states that Phinehas son of Eleazar the priest and ten princes were sent to speak with them.

questions.question: What did the children of Israel accuse the Reubenites, Gadites, and half tribe of Manasseh of, according to Joshua 22:16?
options: Rebelling against the LORD by building an altar
Stealing cattle from Israel
Refusing to fight in battle
Ignoring the laws of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Rebelling against the LORD by building an altar
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:16 says the congregation accused them of rebelling against the LORD by building an altar.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 22:20 references Achan son of Zerah as an example of trespass affecting all Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:20 mentions Achan son of Zerah's trespass causing wrath to fall on all Israel.

questions.question: True or False: The altar built by the tribes was intended for burnt offerings and sacrifices according to their explanation in Joshua 22:26-27.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:26-27 clarifies the altar was not for burnt offerings or sacrifices but as a witness between the tribes.

questions.question: How did Phinehas and the princes react after hearing the explanation of the altar builders in Joshua 22:30-31?
options: It pleased them and they perceived that the LORD was among them
They were angry and prepared for war
They ignored the explanation
They asked for the altar to be dismantled
questions.correctAnswer: It pleased them and they perceived that the LORD was among them
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:30-31 states that Phinehas and the princes were pleased and recognized the LORD's presence among them.

questions.question: True or False: The children of Israel decided to destroy the land of Reuben and Gad after the altar incident according to Joshua 22:33.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:33 says the children of Israel blessed God and did not intend to go up against them in battle.

questions.question: What name did the children of Reuben and Gad give to the altar they built, according to Joshua 22:34?
options: Ed
Witness
Jordan Altar
Peace Altar
questions.correctAnswer: Ed
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:34 states they called the altar Ed as a witness that the LORD is God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Joshua 22:24, the tribes said they built the altar so that in time to come, your children might say to our children, 'What have ye to do with the LORD God of ______?'
options: Israel
Egypt
Babylon
Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:24 explains the altar was built so future generations won't say, 'What have ye to do with the LORD God of Israel?'

medium.title: Joshua Chapter 22 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Joshua Chapter 22 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Joshua 22 teach us about the importance of obedience and faithfulness in daily life?
options: By reminding us to keep the commandments and follow God's ways wholeheartedly
By encouraging us to seek riches and possessions above all
By advising us to isolate ourselves from others
By telling us to build altars for personal glory
questions.correctAnswer: By reminding us to keep the commandments and follow God's ways wholeheartedly
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:2-5 emphasizes obedience to Moses' command, loving the LORD, walking in His ways, and serving Him with all heart and soul, highlighting faithfulness in daily life.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with the fear of causing division in their church family. Based on Joshua 22, what biblical principle can help them maintain unity?
options: Seek understanding and clarify intentions to avoid false accusations
Avoid all communication to prevent conflict
Always assume the worst about others' motives
Build separate places of worship to keep peace
questions.correctAnswer: Seek understanding and clarify intentions to avoid false accusations
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:11-34 shows how misunderstanding about the altar led to conflict, but through dialogue and explanation, unity was restored, teaching us to seek clarity before judgment.

questions.question: What does Joshua 22 teach about being a witness to others in faith and family relationships?
options: Build a testimony that future generations can see and remember
Keep faith private and avoid sharing with others
Focus only on personal salvation without concern for others
Ignore the example you set for children
questions.correctAnswer: Build a testimony that future generations can see and remember
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:24-28 explains the altar was made as a witness between tribes and generations, demonstrating the importance of leaving a godly example for family and community.

questions.question: How does the chapter encourage the practice of humility and contentment in possessions?
options: By blessing the tribes and sending them with their riches, showing gratitude for God's provision
By demanding more wealth and land aggressively
By warning against sharing possessions with others
By instructing them to keep all spoils secret
questions.correctAnswer: By blessing the tribes and sending them with their riches, showing gratitude for God's provision
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:6-8 records Joshua blessing the tribes and sending them with cattle, silver, and gold, reflecting contentment and stewardship of God’s blessings.

questions.question: A fellow believer is tempted to act in rebellion. What lesson from Joshua 22 can encourage perseverance and faithfulness?
options: True loyalty to God means avoiding rebellion and following His commands sincerely
Rebellion can be justified if others misunderstand your actions
It's acceptable to build alternative places of worship for convenience
Ignore warnings about sin as long as intentions are good
questions.correctAnswer: True loyalty to God means avoiding rebellion and following His commands sincerely
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:16-20 warns against rebellion and turning away from the LORD, teaching us the importance of sincere faithfulness and obedience.

questions.question: How can this passage guide a believer’s approach to resolving misunderstandings in the church?
options: Approach with respectful dialogue and seek truth before conflict escalates
Immediately assume guilt and prepare for judgment
Ignore the issue and hope it resolves itself
Hold grudges and refuse to listen
questions.correctAnswer: Approach with respectful dialogue and seek truth before conflict escalates
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:13-31 shows leaders sent to inquire and listen to explanations, resulting in peace, teaching the value of dialogue and understanding in conflict resolution.

questions.question: How does Joshua 22 show the importance of prayer and dependence on God in decision-making?
options: The tribes relied on the LORD’s knowledge and judgment to confirm their intentions
They acted without consulting God or others
They followed only human wisdom without faith
They built altars to compete with the main altar
questions.correctAnswer: The tribes relied on the LORD’s knowledge and judgment to confirm their intentions
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:22-23 expresses reliance on God’s knowledge to judge if their altar was rebellion or not, showing dependence on God’s guidance.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 22 teaches that building a separate altar for burnt offerings beside the LORD’s altar was an act of rebellion.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:16 clearly states the concern that building an altar could be seen as rebellion against the LORD, highlighting the seriousness of faithfulness to God’s commands.

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship can we learn from Joshua 22 regarding sharing blessings?
options: Share the spoils of enemies generously with your brethren as a sign of unity
Keep all wealth for personal gain
Refuse to help others in need
Hide possessions to avoid responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: Share the spoils of enemies generously with your brethren as a sign of unity
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:8 instructs the tribes to return with riches and divide the spoil with brethren, teaching generosity and stewardship within the community.

questions.question: True or False: The altar built by the tribes was meant for sacrifices and burnt offerings according to their explanation.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:26-29 clarifies the altar was not for sacrifices but as a witness to prevent future divisions, showing their intent was not to rival the LORD's altar.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach about the role of church leaders in maintaining peace and unity?
options: Leaders should investigate concerns carefully and promote reconciliation
Leaders should immediately call for war on dissenters
Leaders should ignore conflicts to avoid trouble
Leaders should favor their own tribe over others
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should investigate concerns carefully and promote reconciliation
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:13-31 shows leaders, including Phinehas and princes, investigating the altar issue and resolving it peacefully, illustrating godly leadership in unity.

questions.question: A believer is concerned about how future generations will understand their faith. What does Joshua 22 suggest about this concern?
options: Create visible testimonies and clear examples for children to remember
Keep faith practices secret from children
Avoid teaching children about God to prevent questions
Focus only on personal faith without legacy
questions.correctAnswer: Create visible testimonies and clear examples for children to remember
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:24-28 describes building the altar as a witness so future generations recognize shared faith, emphasizing the importance of spiritual legacy.

questions.question: What does Joshua 22 teach about forgiveness and reconciliation after misunderstanding within the community?
options: After hearing explanations, the community accepted the truth and blessed God, avoiding conflict
The community refused to forgive and went to war immediately
The tribes remained separated permanently
The issue was ignored and left unresolved
questions.correctAnswer: After hearing explanations, the community accepted the truth and blessed God, avoiding conflict
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:30-33 shows how Phinehas and the princes were pleased with the explanation, leading to peace and praise to God, demonstrating reconciliation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The children of Reuben and Gad called the altar ______, signifying it as a witness that the LORD is God.
options: Ed
Gilgal
Bethel
Shiloh
questions.correctAnswer: Ed
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:34 states they called the altar Ed, meaning 'witness,' to testify that the LORD is God and to maintain unity.

questions.question: How can Joshua 22 guide a Christian's work ethic and integrity?
options: By showing faithful obedience to God’s commands and honoring commitments
By encouraging shortcuts to gain wealth quickly
By promoting self-interest over communal responsibility
By avoiding responsibilities to others
questions.correctAnswer: By showing faithful obedience to God’s commands and honoring commitments
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:2-3 highlights the tribes' obedience and faithfulness to God’s commands and care for brethren, modeling integrity and diligence in all affairs.

hard.title: Joshua Chapter 22 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Joshua Chapter 22.

questions.question: Which tribes did Joshua specifically call and commission to return to their land on the other side of the Jordan?
options: Reubenites, Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh
Judah, Ephraim, and Benjamin
Levi, Simeon, and Dan
Naphtali, Asher, and Zebulun
questions.correctAnswer: Reubenites, Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:1 records that Joshua called the Reubenites, Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh to return to their possessions beyond the Jordan.

questions.question: What reason did Joshua give for sending the tribes back to their lands beyond the Jordan?
options: The LORD had given rest to their brethren as promised
They were to conquer new territories
They had failed to obey Moses' command
They were to build a new altar
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD had given rest to their brethren as promised
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:4 explains that because the LORD had given rest to their brethren, Joshua sent them back to their land as Moses had commanded.

questions.question: What specific exhortation did Joshua give to the tribes before sending them away?
options: To love the LORD, walk in all His ways, keep His commandments, cleave unto Him, and serve Him with all heart and soul
To build an altar as a witness between tribes
To take riches and cattle as spoils of war
To avoid contact with other tribes
questions.correctAnswer: To love the LORD, walk in all His ways, keep His commandments, cleave unto Him, and serve Him with all heart and soul
questions.explanation: In Joshua 22:5, Joshua exhorted them to diligently obey God's commandments and serve Him wholeheartedly.

questions.question: What did Joshua bless the tribes with when he sent them back to their possessions?
options: Much riches, cattle, silver, gold, brass, iron, and raiment
Only peace and safety
Land on the west side of Jordan
The gift of prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: Much riches, cattle, silver, gold, brass, iron, and raiment
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:8 describes Joshua blessing them with many riches and spoils from their enemies as they returned to their lands.

questions.question: What action by the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh caused alarm among the rest of Israel?
options: Building a large altar by the Jordan River
Refusing to return to their land
Attacking other Israelite tribes
Offering sacrifices in Shiloh
questions.correctAnswer: Building a large altar by the Jordan River
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:10-11 records that the tribes built a great altar by the Jordan, which the rest of Israel perceived as rebellion.

questions.question: What was the initial reaction of the rest of Israel upon hearing about the altar built by the tribes beyond Jordan?
options: They gathered to go to war against them
They sent gifts to celebrate
They ignored the news
They offered sacrifices at the altar
questions.correctAnswer: They gathered to go to war against them
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:12 says the whole congregation gathered at Shiloh intending to go to war because they thought the altar signified rebellion.

questions.question: Who did Israel send to confront the tribes about the altar, and what was his priestly lineage?
options: Phinehas, son of Eleazar the priest
Aaron, brother of Moses
Eleazar, son of Aaron
Moses, the servant of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Phinehas, son of Eleazar the priest
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:13 identifies Phinehas, son of Eleazar the priest, as the one sent to confront the tribes regarding the altar.

questions.question: What accusation did the leaders of Israel make against the tribes for building the altar?
options: That they were rebelling against the LORD and turning away from following Him
That they were preparing for war against Israel
That they were inviting foreign gods
That they were withholding tithes
questions.correctAnswer: That they were rebelling against the LORD and turning away from following Him
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:16 states the accusation that building the altar was a trespass and rebellion against the LORD.

questions.question: What historical event did the Israelite leaders reference to warn the tribes about the consequences of rebellion?
options: The sin of Achan and the resulting wrath upon Israel
The golden calf incident at Sinai
The plagues in Egypt
The fall of Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: The sin of Achan and the resulting wrath upon Israel
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:20 recalls Achan's sin and the resulting judgment on Israel as a warning against rebellion.

questions.question: How did the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh defend their building of the altar?
options: They claimed it was a witness to future generations that they share in the worship of the LORD
They said it was built for burnt offerings and sacrifices
They denied building the altar
They claimed it was an idol
questions.correctAnswer: They claimed it was a witness to future generations that they share in the worship of the LORD
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:24-28 explains that the altar was not for sacrifices but to serve as a witness that their descendants share in the LORD's worship.

questions.question: True or False: The altar built by the tribes beyond Jordan was intended for offering burnt offerings and sacrifices alongside the main altar in the tabernacle.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:29 clarifies that the altar was not built for burnt offerings or sacrifices, so as not to rebel against the LORD.

questions.question: What was the response of Phinehas and the Israelite leaders after hearing the explanation of the tribes about the altar?
options: They were pleased and recognized the LORD was among them
They immediately destroyed the altar
They declared war against the tribes
They excommunicated the tribes
questions.correctAnswer: They were pleased and recognized the LORD was among them
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:30-31 records that Phinehas and the leaders were pleased and saw that the tribes had not rebelled against the LORD.

questions.question: What name did the tribes give to the altar, and what was its significance?
options: Ed, meaning 'witness' between the tribes that the LORD is God
Gilgal, meaning 'circle' of worship
Shiloh, meaning 'peace'
Bethel, meaning 'house of God'
questions.correctAnswer: Ed, meaning 'witness' between the tribes that the LORD is God
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:34 says the altar was called Ed as a witness that the LORD is God between them and the rest of Israel.

questions.question: How does the building of the altar in Joshua 22 demonstrate the theme of covenant unity and division in the ancient Israelite community?
options: It shows the tension between maintaining unity of worship and respecting tribal boundaries
It reveals a complete schism and rejection of the LORD
It is a symbol of foreign influence and idolatry
It illustrates the end of the Mosaic covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the tension between maintaining unity of worship and respecting tribal boundaries
questions.explanation: The altar incident reflects the complex balance between unity in worship and tribal identity, as the tribes sought to affirm their part in Israel's faith without causing division (Joshua 22:24-28).

questions.question: How does the episode of the altar in Joshua 22 foreshadow later biblical themes concerning centralized worship and the dangers of idolatry?
options: It anticipates Deuteronomy's emphasis on one central sanctuary and warns against unauthorized altars
It endorses multiple altars and decentralized worship
It predicts the destruction of the temple in Jerusalem
It establishes that sacrifices can be made anywhere
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates Deuteronomy's emphasis on one central sanctuary and warns against unauthorized altars
questions.explanation: The concern over the altar parallels Deuteronomy 12's command for centralized worship and the prohibition of unauthorized altars, highlighting covenant faithfulness (Joshua 22:19, cf. Deut 12).

theological.title: Joshua Chapter 22 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Joshua Chapter 22 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary reason Joshua called the Reubenites, Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh in Joshua 22?
options: To commend their faithfulness and obedience to God's commandments
To rebuke them for building an altar
To assign them new territories west of Jordan
To draft them for a military campaign
questions.correctAnswer: To commend their faithfulness and obedience to God's commandments
questions.explanation: Joshua acknowledged their obedience to Moses' commands and their faithfulness in not abandoning their brethren (Joshua 22:2-3). This reflects God's call to obedience as seen in Deuteronomy 6:5 and Hebrews 11:8. God's faithfulness to His promises is a key theme in Scripture (2 Timothy 2:13).

questions.question: What specific command did Joshua emphasize to the tribes before sending them back to their land?
options: To love the LORD their God and walk in all His ways
To build an altar as a witness between tribes
To conquer all remaining enemies in the land
To offer sacrifices only at Shiloh
questions.correctAnswer: To love the LORD their God and walk in all His ways
questions.explanation: Joshua urged them to diligently keep the commandments of Moses, love God, walk in His ways, and serve Him wholeheartedly (Joshua 22:5), echoing the Shema in Deuteronomy 6:5 and the call to wholehearted devotion in Matthew 22:37-38.

questions.question: According to Joshua 22, what did the tribes carry back with them to their possessions?
options: Riches including cattle, silver, gold, brass, iron, and raiment
Only their families and tents
The Ark of the Covenant
Sacrificial animals for offerings
questions.correctAnswer: Riches including cattle, silver, gold, brass, iron, and raiment
questions.explanation: Joshua instructed them to return with much wealth, including cattle and various metals, reflecting God's blessing upon them (Joshua 22:8). This shows God's providence and reward for obedience (Psalm 128:2; Deuteronomy 28:4).

questions.question: What action of the tribes caused concern and anger among the rest of Israel?
options: Building a large altar by the Jordan River
Refusing to fight against Canaanites
Taking spoils without permission
Moving their tents without consulting Joshua
questions.correctAnswer: Building a large altar by the Jordan River
questions.explanation: When the other tribes heard that Reuben, Gad, and half Manasseh had built a great altar by the Jordan, they perceived it as rebellion and gathered to war (Joshua 22:10-12). This highlights the seriousness of maintaining covenant worship centralized as commanded in Deuteronomy 12:5-7.

questions.question: What was the accusation made by the leaders of Israel against the tribes who built the altar?
options: That they had rebelled against the LORD by turning away from following Him
That they had stolen land from other tribes
That they had refused to fight enemies
That they had disobeyed Joshua's military orders
questions.correctAnswer: That they had rebelled against the LORD by turning away from following Him
questions.explanation: The leaders accused them of trespassing against God by building an altar, which they interpreted as rebellion from following the LORD (Joshua 22:16). This reflects the biblical theme of covenant faithfulness and the dangers of idolatry and division (Exodus 20:3-5; 1 Kings 18:21).

questions.question: How did the accused tribes respond to the charge of rebellion regarding the altar?
options: They explained the altar was not for burnt offerings but a witness between tribes
They admitted their rebellion and asked for forgiveness
They denied building the altar
They declared independence from Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They explained the altar was not for burnt offerings but a witness between tribes
questions.explanation: They clarified that the altar was not for sacrifices but a symbolic witness to prevent future disputes about their share in the LORD (Joshua 22:24-28). This emphasizes the importance of unity and testimony among God's people (Ephesians 4:3-6; John 17:21).

questions.question: What historical example did the Israelites invoke to warn the tribes about the consequences of rebellion?
options: The sin of Achan and its consequences on the whole congregation
The golden calf incident at Mount Sinai
The rebellion of Korah and his followers
The fall of Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: The sin of Achan and its consequences on the whole congregation
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:20 references Achan's sin, where his individual disobedience brought wrath on all Israel, illustrating the communal consequences of sin and rebellion (Numbers 16; Joshua 7). This aligns with biblical teaching on corporate responsibility and holiness (1 Corinthians 5:6).

questions.question: What was the significance of the altar’s name 'Ed' as given by the tribes?
options: It means a witness between the tribes that the LORD is God
It signifies the altar was a place of sacrifice
It means 'rebellion' as a warning
It was named after a leader who built it
questions.correctAnswer: It means a witness between the tribes that the LORD is God
questions.explanation: The altar was called Ed to serve as a witness that the LORD is God, signifying unity and shared faith despite geographic separation (Joshua 22:34). This displays the biblical principle of testimony and remembrance (Exodus 17:15; Psalm 78:4).

questions.question: What theological truth is reflected by the tribes’ concern that their children might say, 'Ye have no part in the LORD'?
options: The importance of covenant identity and continuity across generations
The need to build separate places of worship
That territorial boundaries determine God's favor
That sacrifices outside the tabernacle are invalid
questions.correctAnswer: The importance of covenant identity and continuity across generations
questions.explanation: Their concern (Joshua 22:24-25) reflects the biblical emphasis on passing covenant faith to descendants, ensuring unity and fear of the LORD (Deuteronomy 6:7; Psalm 78:6-7). This underscores the communal and generational dimension of salvation history.

questions.question: What was the reaction of Phinehas and the Israelite princes after hearing the tribes’ explanation?
options: They were pleased and recognized that no rebellion had occurred
They demanded the altar be torn down immediately
They accused the tribes of idolatry
They prepared to wage war against them
questions.correctAnswer: They were pleased and recognized that no rebellion had occurred
questions.explanation: Phinehas and the leaders accepted the explanation with joy, perceiving the LORD among them and that no trespass had been committed (Joshua 22:30-31). This illustrates the biblical value of reconciliation and seeking understanding (Matthew 18:15-17; Romans 12:18).

questions.question: How does the episode of the altar in Joshua 22 contribute to our understanding of God's holiness and unity in worship?
options: It stresses that worship must be centralized and unified to honor God’s holiness
It shows that any altar is acceptable for sacrifice
It indicates that geographical separation dissolves covenant obligations
It permits independent worship practices without accountability
questions.correctAnswer: It stresses that worship must be centralized and unified to honor God’s holiness
questions.explanation: The concern over the altar's construction and the fear of rebellion highlight God's demand for unified worship (Joshua 22:19). Centralized worship is consistent with Deuteronomy 12:5-14 and the New Testament emphasis on the body of Christ worshiping in unity (John 4:23-24; 1 Corinthians 1:10).

questions.question: What does Joshua 22 teach about the relationship between obedience to God and communal peace among His people?
options: Obedience to God's commandments fosters unity and prevents conflict
Obedience leads to isolation of tribes
Communal peace is unrelated to obedience
Conflict is inevitable regardless of obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's commandments fosters unity and prevents conflict
questions.explanation: The misunderstanding about the altar nearly led to war, but truth and obedience brought peace (Joshua 22:12-33). This corresponds with biblical teaching that obedience to God promotes peace (Psalm 119:165; Romans 12:18) and unity within the covenant community (Ephesians 4:3).

questions.question: How does the building of the altar in Joshua 22 relate to the doctrine of the covenant in biblical theology?
options: It serves as a physical witness to the covenant unity despite tribal divisions
It breaks the covenant by creating a new place of worship
It replaces the covenant established at Sinai
It nullifies the need for sacrifices at the tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a physical witness to the covenant unity despite tribal divisions
questions.explanation: The altar was meant as a witness to maintain covenant identity and unity between tribes across the Jordan (Joshua 22:27-28). This aligns with biblical themes of covenant signs (Genesis 17:11; Exodus 12:13) and the unity of God's people (Galatians 3:28).

questions.question: What does the incident in Joshua 22 reveal about the nature of sin and its impact on the community?
options: Sin affects the whole community and requires communal discernment and correction
Sin is only a private matter with no communal consequences
Only leaders are responsible for sin
Sin can be ignored if intentions are good
questions.correctAnswer: Sin affects the whole community and requires communal discernment and correction
questions.explanation: The fear of rebellion and reference to Achan's sin illustrate how sin impacts the entire covenant community and necessitates communal response (Joshua 22:16-20). This reflects biblical teaching on corporate sin and church discipline (Leviticus 4:13-21; 1 Corinthians 5:6-7).

questions.question: In what way does Joshua 22 reflect God's providential care over His people during transitions and relocations?
options: God provides rest and blessing, guiding His people to their possessions with peace
God abandons His people when they move
God requires constant war to maintain territory
God's blessing is limited to the land west of the Jordan
questions.correctAnswer: God provides rest and blessing, guiding His people to their possessions with peace
questions.explanation: Joshua 22:4 shows that God gave rest to the brethren, enabling peaceful return to their lands, illustrating God's providential faithfulness (Psalm 121:8; Hebrews 4:9-10). God's care extends beyond conquest to sustaining His people in covenant rest.

questions.question: How does the episode in Joshua 22 underscore the importance of communication and understanding within the body of Christ?
options: Misunderstandings can lead to conflict, but honest dialogue fosters peace and unity
Silence is the best way to avoid conflict
Each tribe should act independently without consultation
Assuming the worst prevents future problems
questions.correctAnswer: Misunderstandings can lead to conflict, but honest dialogue fosters peace and unity
questions.explanation: The initial assumption of rebellion led to mobilization for war, but the dialogue led by Phinehas clarified intentions and maintained unity (Joshua 22:12-33). This aligns with biblical principles of conflict resolution and reconciliation (Matthew 18:15-17; James 1:19).
